awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on mixing events that occur in sheared flows close to boundaries and in other complex environments. For example, shear-driven mixing events near the ocean surface flux heat and CO2 into the ocean interior. Previous studies of shear-driven mixing events have assumed that the event is isolated in space and time, i.e. it begins with smooth, laminar flow and is located far from any boundary or other significant flow structure that could impact its evolution. This research will address the effects of spatially proximate influences such as the ocean surface, the bottom, or another nearby mixing event. The main tool will be a sequence of direct numerical simulations of sheared flows with either a boundary or another flow structure close enough to influence the mixing. Results will be used to guide parameterization of turbulent fluxes near the ocean surface and in deep ocean currents such as dense overflows. The results will be useful in understanding dense bottom currents, surface mixed layers and in parameterizing the resulting turbulence. The project will support a postdoc and a graduate student. Both of these junior scientists will learn and use advanced numerical simulation skills. In addition, both will have the opportunity to take part in research cruises to observe shear-driven turbulence.


The Kelvin-Helmholtz (KH) ansatz is a common and useful model for ocean turbulence. It is often used to describe turbulence near boundaries, e.g., in near-bottom gravity currents or at the base of a surface mixed layer. While linear theory tells us that boundary proximity can affect the basic length and time scales of KH billows, little is known of the effect on the nonlinear evolution and subsequent mixing. For example, KH billows with lengths up to 300m have been observed within 50m of the surface in the equatorial Pacific. In these cases, boundary proximity is likely to have a large effect on the resulting mixing and on air-sea property transports. In isolation, KH instability becomes turbulent via a well- explored sequence of secondary instabilities. This sequence is sensitive to the details of the initial shear flow, and it has a great influence on the amount of mixing that is ultimately achieved. It is hypothesized that a nearby boundary will alter the sequence of secondary instabilities and thereby change the amount of mixing. Even far from boundaries, e.g. in the thermocline, mixing events occur sporadically and may therefore feel the influence of other, nearby events. Using the petascale machines at UCAR,  a sequence of direct simulations will be made of KH events in the presence of boundaries and other flow features. Results will be used to interpret observations of shear-driven mixing events near the surface in the equatorial oceans and to broaden our understanding of the KH instability mechanism as it operates throughout the ocean.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this three-stage project we explored the development of turbulence in shear layers. “Shear” refers to a horizontal wind or current that changes with depth. In a shear layer, the wind or current changes suddenly over a thin transition layer. For example, shear layers are often found a few hundred feet above the Earth’s surface where they cause problems for aircraft taking off or landing. A shear layer may spawn large vortices called Kelvin-Helmholtz (KH) billows. These cause turbulence and drive vertical transport of fluid properties such as heat. In the equatorial oceans, shear in the upper few hundred feet creates turbulence that draws heat from the surface down into the deep ocean, effectively cooling the atmosphere. This effect is strongest in La Nina conditions, where it temporarily counters atmospheric warming due to the greenhouse effect. 

It is well known that the atmosphere is a chaotic system, which is why weather forecasts are limited to 7-10 days. The evolution of a shear layer is in this sense a microcosm of the weather - as it breaks down into turbulence, its detailed evolution is essentially unpredictable. One therefore wonders whether macroscopic aspects of practical importance, such as heat transport, might also be unpredictable. In the first of our three studies, we quantified the uncertainty due to this so-called “butterfly effect” and described the mechanisms that cause it. We found that even a tiny change in the initial state of a shear layer can double the resulting vertical transport.

Previous studies of shear layers have assumed that the layer is isolated, whereas shear layers in nature are affected by nearby features such as the land or ocean surface or, in some cases, other shear layers. This observation inspired our second and third studies. The second focused on the effect of a nearby boundary. We found that boundary effects begin when the shear layer is separated from the boundary by a distance of about twice its thickness. One such effect is the suppression of “pairing”. In laboratory and numerical experiments, adjacent KH billows often merge to form fewer, larger billows, greatly increasing the vertical transport. However, pairing is rarely observed in the atmosphere. Our results suggest that the boundary is responsible for this discrepancy. 

Our third study examined the case where two shear layers are centered at nearby depths. We found that pairing and vertical transport are strongest when the two layers are close together - specifically, when the separation distance is less than the thickness of the layers. When the separation is greater than this, pairing and mixing are much weaker. Whereas the boundary effect becomes gradually stronger with increasing proximity, the effect of neighboring shear layers changes suddenly as the critical separation distance is exceeded. This is an example of the aformentioned butterfly effect, wherein a small change in the initial state can result in a large change later on.

The importance of the butterfly effect implies that, to understand turbulent transport in shear layers, we must adopt a technique that is standard in weather and climate forecasting: we conduct several simulations with slight changes to the initial flow, then average the results to estimate the most probable outcome.
